discourse_list.title: [Financial Times] The future of stablecoins is commercial bank money

content.content: ft.com   Subscribe to read | Financial Times News, analysis and comment from the Financial Times, the worldʼs leading global business publication       A few highlights from this interesting article regarding stablecoins in a normalized rate environment (>2%) and adapting to potential regulatory changes.  Issuers of these stablecoins have thrived while nominal interest rates have been near zero. With high positive interest rates, the opportunity cost of holding zero-interest stablecoins increases and the issuers lose business.   There is a problem though, at least for the EU with the Regulation on Markets in Crypto-assets (MiCA) that is expected to come into force in 2024. This proscribes the paying of interest on money tokens. That would force issuers to adopt a business model that is only sustainable with near-zero interest rates. Interesting take - In order to compete in a rising rate environment, stablecoin issuers might consider more regulation? I am not sure about this one but its a theory.  If interest rates deviate significantly from zero, stablecoin issuers are likely to apply for banking licences to benefit from the regulatory advantages. Existing banks will probably introduce tokenised deposits in order to compete. Stablecoin issuers, as intermediaries, will probably be only a temporary phenomenon. What will remain is commercial bank money with enhanced technical functionality.

Interesting article. Competing pressures are developing. Interest rates rising are making non interest stablecoins seem unattractive but high inflation creates demand for safe investments. Re: regulation, we should closely monitor European countries development to understand its implications
